issues.title: Electric Water Pump and Thermostat Failure
issues.symptoms: Overheating, coolant warning, reduced power mode, water pump whining, engine shut down
issues.description: The E90 generation was the first to use BMW's electric water pump and electronic thermostat. Both components have high failure rates, typically between 60,000-100,000 miles. When the water pump fails, there is no warning - the engine can overheat rapidly. The pump may also become noisy before complete failure. These are considered wear items requiring proactive replacement.
fixes: Proactive water pump replacement at 80,000 miles
Replace thermostat at the same time
Use OEM or quality German-made parts (Pierburg/VDO)
Don't ignore any coolant warning lights
Consider replacing when doing timing chain service (N20/N54/N55)

repairCosts.notes: Electric water pump on N52/N54. Thermostat often done together.

issues.title: Oil Leaks (Valve Cover and Oil Filter Housing)
issues.symptoms: Oil smell, visible oil on engine, oil spots under car, smoke from engine bay, low oil warning
issues.description: The E90's N52 and N5x engines develop oil leaks as they age. The valve cover gasket is a very common leak point due to the plastic valve cover warping from heat. The oil filter housing gasket (OFHG) is another notorious leak point that can drip oil onto hot exhaust components, creating fire risk and smoke.
fixes: Valve cover gasket replacement - consider replacing entire valve cover (plastic warps)
Oil filter housing gasket - common leak, relatively accessible
Oil cooler gasket (if equipped)
Eccentric shaft sensor seal (N52)
Address oil leaks promptly - oil on exhaust is fire hazard

repairCosts.notes: Valve cover and oil filter housing gaskets common.

issues.title: High Pressure Fuel Pump Failure (N54/N55)
issues.symptoms: Long crank time, rough idle, loss of power, engine stalling, check engine light, limp mode
issues.description: The N54 and early N55 engines use a mechanical high-pressure fuel pump (HPFP) driven by the intake camshaft. Early versions were prone to failure, causing drivability issues or complete stalling. BMW extended warranty coverage on early pumps. Later revisions improved reliability.
fixes: Check for updated HPFP part number (several revisions exist)
Replace with latest revision pump if experiencing issues
Monitor fuel pressure with diagnostic tool if symptoms appear
Later production N55 engines have improved pumps

repairCosts.notes: N54 only. High pressure fuel pump failure causes rough running.

issues.title: Fuel Injector Problems (N54/N55)
issues.symptoms: Rough idle, misfires, check engine light, poor fuel economy, hesitation
issues.description: The direct injection N54 engine is known for fuel injector issues, including leaking and failure to atomize fuel properly. The piezoelectric injectors are expensive and can fail individually or multiple at once. Index 12 injectors are the latest revision with improved reliability. N55 injectors are generally more reliable but can still fail.
fixes: Replace failed injectors with latest index revision (Index 12 for N54)
Replace all injectors at once if multiple failures (common on N54)
Verify injector index before ordering
Use quality fuel to reduce injector wear
Walnut blast intake valves while replacing injectors

repairCosts.notes: N54 piezo injectors. Replace as set if multiple fail.

issues.title: VANOS Solenoid and System Issues
issues.symptoms: Rough idle, loss of power, engine rattle, check engine light, fault codes for VANOS
issues.description: All E90 engines use VANOS variable valve timing. The VANOS solenoids can fail or become clogged with oil sludge, especially with extended oil change intervals. The N54 and N55 also have VANOS-related issues with the adjustment units themselves, including the bolts backing out and damaging components.
fixes: Replace VANOS solenoids (relatively inexpensive service)
Clean VANOS system if sludge buildup suspected
Use quality oil and don't exceed oil change intervals
N54/N55: VANOS bolt recall - verify upgrade bolts installed
Timing chain tensioner service may be needed (N20)

repairCosts.notes: Solenoid failures cause rough idle and codes.

issues.title: Turbo Wastegate Rattle (N54)
issues.symptoms: Rattling noise on cold start, rattle under load, metallic rattling from engine bay
issues.description: The N54's twin turbochargers develop wastegate rattle due to wear in the wastegate actuator mechanism. The rattle is typically worst on cold startup and may diminish when warm. While the turbos still function with this rattle, it indicates wear that will eventually require turbo replacement or rebuild.
fixes: Wastegate actuator replacement or adjustment (temporary fix)
Turbo rebuild with upgraded wastegate components
Turbo replacement (OEM or upgraded aftermarket units)
Upgraded pure turbos or Vargas units for performance builds

repairCosts.notes: N54 turbos. Wastegate rattle common. Replacement often in pairs.

issues.title: Carbon Buildup on Intake Valves (Direct Injection Engines)
issues.symptoms: Rough idle, misfires, reduced power, poor fuel economy, hesitation
issues.description: All direct injection engines (N54, N55, N20) are susceptible to carbon buildup on the intake valves. Because fuel is injected directly into the cylinder rather than onto the valves, there is no fuel washing the valves clean. Over time, carbon deposits accumulate, affecting airflow and performance. Walnut blasting is the standard solution.
fixes: Walnut shell blasting every 50,000-80,000 miles
Chemical treatments (less effective but less invasive)
Catch can installation to reduce oil vapor deposits
Use quality fuel with good detergent additives
Combine with injector replacement or other intake work

repairCosts.notes: N54 direct injection. Walnut blasting required every 50-60k.

issues.title: Rod Bearing Wear (S65 M3)
issues.symptoms: Knocking noise, engine rattle, low oil pressure, metal in oil
issues.description: The S65 V8 in the E90/E92/E93 M3 has a known rod bearing wear issue. The factory bearings can wear prematurely, especially with track use or aggressive driving. If caught early, bearings can be replaced. If ignored, bearing failure leads to catastrophic engine damage. Oil analysis is crucial for monitoring.
fixes: Regular oil analysis to detect bearing wear early (essential for M3 owners)
Proactive rod bearing replacement (BE bearings recommended)
Use appropriate oil (10W-60 recommended for track use)
Proper warm-up and cool-down procedures
Address any abnormal noise immediately

repairCosts.notes: S65 V8 (M3) only. Preventive replacement recommended.

issues.title: Timing Chain and Guide Issues (N20/N54/N55)
issues.symptoms: Timing chain rattle, rough running, check engine light, chain stretch codes, failure to start
issues.description: The N20 four-cylinder engine has documented timing chain stretch and guide wear issues, sometimes at relatively low mileage. The N54 and N55 six-cylinders can also have chain and guide wear at high mileage. Ignoring chain stretch can lead to jumped timing and engine damage.
fixes: Monitor for timing chain stretch via diagnostic codes
Replace chain, guides, and tensioner as a kit
N20: Known issue - may be covered under BMW's extended coverage
Consider proactive replacement on high-mileage N54/N55
Replace water pump and thermostat while apart

repairCosts.notes: N54/N55 timing chain stretch. Often guides and tensioner too.

guides.title: Complete Suspension Refresh
guides.description: Full front and rear suspension rebuild for the E90's modern multi-link design including control arms, thrust arms, and rear trailing arm bushings to restore factory handling.
tools: RTAB press tool or hydraulic press
steps: Raise vehicle and support on jack stands at all four corners.
Remove all wheels and photograph suspension for reference.
Soak all suspension bolts with penetrating oil before removal.
Begin with front suspension - remove sway bar end links (44 ft-lbs torque spec).
Remove tie rod end nut (52 ft-lbs) and separate from knuckle using puller.
Remove lower control arm ball joint nut and separate from knuckle (122 ft-lbs).
Remove control arm bracket bolts from subframe (74 ft-lbs) and remove arm.
Remove thrust arm bolts - 74 ft-lbs at subframe, 122 ft-lbs at knuckle.
For struts: mark camber position, remove upper mount nuts (25 ft-lbs), remove pinch bolt (60 ft-lbs).
Use spring compressor to disassemble strut and replace mount/bearing.
Install new front components with correct torque specs.
For rear suspension: support trailing arm before removing bolts.
For RTAB replacement: remove trailing arm rear bolt, press out old bushings.
Press new RTABs into trailing arm - note orientation.
Remove and replace rear control arms as needed.
Reassemble all components - torque bushings at ride height.
Install wheels and lower vehicle - bounce corners to settle.
Professional 4-wheel alignment required immediately.
tips: E90 RTABs are critical for rear-end stability - prioritize if worn.
The E90 uses similar suspension to E46 but with updated components.
Meyle HD bushings are recommended for longer service life.
Consider replacing both front thrust arms even if only one shows wear.
The E92 M3 uses a different rear subframe design - verify part compatibility.
warnings: RTAB replacement requires a special press tool - don't attempt with hammers.
Worn RTABs cause dangerous rear-end instability - don't delay repairs.
Spring compressors are dangerous - follow tool instructions exactly.
Never strike ball joints directly - use proper separator tools.
M3 models have unique suspension components - verify correct parts.

guides.title: Rust Prevention and Inspection
guides.description: Rust inspection guide for the E90, covering known problem areas and preventive treatments for this generally well-protected chassis.
steps: E90s are well-protected but still require inspection, especially salt-belt cars.
Clean undercarriage thoroughly before inspection.
Inspect rocker panels by tapping with screwdriver - soft spots indicate rust.
Check jack points for rust perforation - common failure point.
Inspect rear wheel arches from inside trunk and behind liners.
Check door bottoms by opening fully and inspecting from below.
Examine front fender mounting lips where mud collects.
Look at subframe mounting areas for any corrosion.
For surface rust: wire brush to bare metal, apply rust converter.
Prime with epoxy primer, then topcoat.
For rust-through: cut out damaged metal, weld in patches.
Seal all repaired areas with seam sealer.
Apply cavity wax to all hollow sections - rockers, frame rails.
Treat inner fenders and underbody with rust preventive.
Check sunroof drains if equipped - clogs cause interior rust.
Ensure all drain plugs are clear in floor and trunk.
Document condition for future reference.
tips: E90s are generally more rust-resistant than earlier BMWs due to better galvanization.
Most rust issues are from stone chips, salt, and debris rather than design flaws.
Annual Fluid Film application prevents most rust development.
Check behind plastic fender liners - they trap moisture.
Convertible E93 models may have additional rust points around top mechanism.
warnings: Always wear respirator when grinding rust.
Check for brake lines and wiring before welding.
Fire extinguisher must be accessible during any welding.
Structural rust near suspension mounts requires professional attention.
Don't ignore small rust spots - they spread quickly.

guides.title: Electrical System Service
guides.description: Complete electrical system service covering the E90's common issues including ignition coils, VANOS solenoids, battery registration, and module coding.
tools: ISTA/INPA diagnostic software or compatible tool
steps: Disconnect battery and wait 10 minutes before electrical work.
Start with diagnostic scan - E90s require proper software for full diagnosis.
For ignition coil replacement: remove engine cover, disconnect coil connectors.
Remove 10mm bolt, pull coils straight up, install new coils.
For VANOS solenoid replacement: locate solenoids on cylinder head.
Disconnect connector, remove mounting bolt, replace O-rings on new solenoid.
For battery replacement: note that E90 requires registration in DME.
Remove old battery, install new, register using ISTA or compatible tool.
Unregistered battery causes improper charging and reduced battery life.
For eccentric shaft sensor (N52): located on rear of cylinder head.
Remove electrical connector and sensor bolt, install new with fresh seal.
For blend door actuator: remove glovebox for access.
Disconnect actuator connector, remove mounting screws, install new.
Clean all electrical grounds and apply dielectric grease.
Clear fault codes and perform adaptation reset as needed.
Test all systems thoroughly after repairs.
tips: E90 requires proper diagnostic software - generic OBD2 scanners miss many faults.
Battery MUST be registered after replacement or it will overcharge and fail early.
Ignition coil failure is common - misfires often traced to coils.
VANOS solenoids should be OEM - aftermarket quality varies significantly.
The N54 engine has many electrical components - systematic diagnosis is key.
warnings: Always disconnect battery before electrical work.
Battery registration is mandatory - skipping causes charging system issues.
N54/N55 charge pipe can blow off under boost - upgrade to aluminum recommended.
Don't clear fault codes without documenting them first.
SRS (airbag) system requires special procedures - don't probe these circuits.

guides.title: Interior Restoration
guides.description: Complete interior refresh for the E90 covering leather care, trim restoration, iDrive service, and common wear items.
tools: Torx driver set (T15, T20, T25, T30)
steps: Document all components with photos before disassembly.
Remove seats for access - 4 bolts each, disconnect electrical connectors.
For leather: clean with dedicated leather cleaner in small sections.
Address cracks with leather filler, sand smooth, apply dye.
Condition all leather surfaces after repair.
For headliner: remove sun visors, dome lights, A-pillar trim, grab handles.
Remove headliner board through rear door opening.
Strip old fabric and foam, apply new fabric from center outward.
For aluminum trim: options include re-brushing, vinyl wrap, or hydrodip.
If peeling, vinyl wrap provides durable finish without disassembly.
For iDrive: diagnose controller vs screen issues with proper scanner.
Controller rebuild services available for sticky buttons or failed scroll.
Replace cabin air filter - accessed behind glovebox.
Clean all HVAC vents with detailing brushes.
Replace door seals if wind noise present.
Apply UV protectant to dashboard and trim.
Reassemble in reverse order.
tips: E90 aluminum trim peels and flakes - vinyl wrap is popular solution.
Sport seats have aggressive bolsters that wear faster.
iDrive controller failures are common - rebuilds available.
The E90 uses Dakota leather on most models - responds well to conditioning.
Check for sunroof drain clogs if headliner shows water stains.
warnings: Headliner adhesive fumes are harmful - work in well-ventilated area.
E90 seats have side airbags - disconnect battery before removal.
Don't force trim clips - they break easily when cold.
iDrive coding requires proper software - incorrect coding causes issues.
Test all electrical after seat reinstallation - connectors can be fragile.

suspension.notes: Tighten in star pattern, dry torque

diyGuides.title: Oil Change
diyGuides.description: Complete oil and filter change for N52, N54, and N55 engines.
tools: 36mm socket or oil filter cap wrench
steps: Warm the engine for 2-3 minutes to thin the oil.
Raise the front of the car and secure on jack stands, or use ramps.
Locate the oil drain plug on the oil pan - passenger side.
Position drain pan and remove the 17mm drain plug.
Allow oil to drain completely - 10 minutes minimum.
Replace the aluminum crush washer on the drain plug.
Reinstall drain plug and torque to 18 ft-lbs (25 Nm).
The oil filter housing is on top of the engine - remove cap with 36mm socket.
Lift out the old filter element and remove the O-ring from the cap.
Install the new filter element onto the center post.
Lubricate the new O-ring with fresh oil and seat it in the cap groove.
Reinstall the filter cap and torque to 25 ft-lbs (34 Nm).
Add oil: 6.5 quarts (N52), 7.0 quarts (N54/N55). Use 5W-30 BMW LL-01.
Start engine, check for leaks, shut off and verify level after 2 minutes.
tips: The E90 uses a cartridge filter - the housing stays on the engine.
Always replace the O-ring to prevent leaks from the filter housing cap.
N54/N55 turbo engines benefit from 0W-40 in extreme temperatures.

diyGuides.title: Brake Pad Replacement
diyGuides.description: Front and rear brake pad replacement with electronic sensor reset.
steps: Loosen lug bolts while the car is on the ground.
Raise and support the car on jack stands, remove wheel.
Disconnect the brake pad wear sensor connector and unclip from bracket.
Remove the two 7mm Allen caliper guide pin bolts from behind the caliper.
Pivot the caliper up and secure - do not let it hang by the brake hose.
Remove the old pads from the caliper bracket.
Inspect rotor for wear, grooves, or minimum thickness markings.
Clean the pad contact surfaces with wire brush and brake cleaner.
Open brake fluid reservoir cap, then compress caliper piston fully.
Apply brake grease to the back of new pads and contact points.
Install new pads - the pad with wear sensor hole goes on the inner side.
Install new wear sensor into the inner pad (sensors are typically one-time use).
Pivot caliper down and reinstall guide pins to 22 ft-lbs (30 Nm).
Reconnect wear sensor, reinstall wheel, torque lugs to 89 ft-lbs (120 Nm).
Reset brake pad wear indicator using ISTA or compatible diagnostic tool.
tips: E90 electronic wear sensors are usually on front left and rear right.
After replacement, reset the CBS (Condition Based Service) brake indicator.
Bed new pads with 5-10 moderate stops from 30 mph before driving normally.

diyGuides.title: Spark Plug Replacement
diyGuides.description: Spark plug replacement for all E90 engine variants.
steps: Allow engine to cool completely - spark plugs can seize in hot aluminum.
Remove the engine cover by pulling up on the four corners.
Disconnect the electrical connector from each ignition coil.
Remove the 10mm bolt or T30 screw holding each coil in place.
Pull each ignition coil straight up and out of the spark plug well.
Use compressed air or vacuum to clean debris from the spark plug wells.
Using spark plug socket and extension, remove each spark plug.
Inspect old plugs for wear, fouling, or damage - note condition.
Gap new plugs if necessary (most modern plugs are pre-gapped).
Thread new plugs in by hand to prevent cross-threading.
Torque spark plugs to 17 ft-lbs (23 Nm) - do not overtighten.
Reinstall ignition coils and secure with bolt/screw.
Reconnect coil electrical connectors until they click.
Reinstall engine cover.
tips: N54 uses 6 spark plugs; the N52 uses 6 spark plugs - one per cylinder.
Use NGK or Bosch OEM-equivalent plugs for best results.
Inspect ignition coils while replacing plugs - replace if cracked or worn.

diyGuides.title: Oil Filter Housing Gasket
diyGuides.description: Replace the notorious leaking oil filter housing gasket.
steps: Remove the engine cover and intake snorkel for access.
Drain some coolant - the oil cooler (if equipped) ties into the cooling system.
Remove the oil filter cap and filter element.
Disconnect any electrical connectors on or near the housing (oil pressure sensor).
Remove the 3-4 E10 or E12 Torx bolts holding the filter housing to the block.
Carefully pry the housing off the block - it may stick from the old gasket.
Remove the old gasket and clean both mating surfaces thoroughly.
Remove old O-rings from the oil cooler ports if equipped.
Install new gasket onto the housing - it should seat into the groove.
Install new oil cooler O-rings if equipped.
Position housing on block and hand-thread the mounting bolts.
Torque mounting bolts to 18 ft-lbs (25 Nm) in a cross pattern.
Reinstall filter element and cap, torque cap to 25 ft-lbs (34 Nm).
Reconnect electrical connectors and refill coolant if drained.
Start engine and check for leaks at the housing.
tips: The OFHG is one of the most common oil leaks on N52 and N54 engines.
Oil dripping onto the exhaust can cause smoke and fire - don't delay this repair.
Some kits include the oil cooler gaskets - inspect and replace if questionable.
Check the eccentric shaft sensor seal (N52) while you have access.

buyersGuide.overview: The BMW E90/E92/E93 3 Series (2006-2013) represents BMW's transition into the modern era with more technology, more power, and more complexity. The N52 and N54/N55 turbocharged inline-sixes offered impressive performance, while the E90 M3 with its screaming 4.0L V8 S65 engine became an instant classic. Build quality remained high, and these cars offer modern amenities with the last vestiges of hydraulic steering feel. However, the increased complexity means higher maintenance costs, and the turbocharged engines have known reliability concerns that must be addressed.

variants.name: 325i / 328i
variants.description: The naturally aspirated models with N52 3.0L inline-six producing 215-230 hp. Reliable and efficient. The 328i is the sweet spot for daily driving.

variants.name: 335i
variants.description: The turbocharged model with N54 (2007-2010) or N55 (2011-2013) producing 300-300 hp. Serious performance potential but requires more maintenance.

variants.name: 335is
variants.description: Special edition with N54 engine producing 320 hp, 7-speed DCT available, and M Sport styling. Limited production.

variants.name: M3 (E90/E92/E93)
variants.description: The legendary S65 4.0L V8 producing 414 hp and revving to 8,400 rpm. Available as sedan, coupe, and convertible. Manual and DCT options.

variants.name: 328xi / 335xi
variants.description: All-wheel drive variants. xDrive system is sophisticated but adds weight and complexity.

items.detail: Known failure point causing rough running and reduced power. Extended warranty covered many but not all.
Turbos develop wastegate rattle, eventually requiring turbo replacement. Listen on cold start.
Fuel injectors can develop leaks causing rough running and codes. Index 12+ injectors preferred.
Plastic charge pipe can crack under boost, especially with tune. Aftermarket aluminum recommended.
Extremely common leak point on N54 and N55. Check for oil around the filter housing.
Oil leaks from the valve cover gasket are common with age.
The S65 V8 has known rod bearing wear issues, especially with track use. Check service records.
The individual throttle bodies can fail. Check for codes and rough running.
Complex variable valve timing system can develop issues. Listen for rattle.
Some S65 engines consume oil. Check level and ask about consumption rate.
Electric water pump can fail without warning. Common on all E90 engines.
Electric thermostat fails, causing overcooling or overheating.
Coil packs fail causing misfires. Usually replaced in sets.
E90 requires battery registration when replaced. Verify proper charging.
If equipped, check iDrive controller and screen functionality.
Front control arm bushings wear causing clunking and vague steering.
RTAB wear affects handling and causes tire wear.
The dual-clutch M DCT requires fluid service. Check for shudder or harsh shifts.
Rear differential can develop leaks. Check for oil on the inside of rear wheels.
E90s are better galvanized than predecessors, but check rockers and wheel wells.
Plastic headlight lenses yellow and haze with age.
Check for wind noise indicating worn seals.
Sport seat bolsters wear on driver's side entry point.

project.description: High-mileage cars with deferred maintenance or known issues. N54 cars often need turbos.

driver.description: Running well but with some wear. Budget for maintenance items. Many good 328i examples here.

excellent.description: Well-maintained 335is or clean M3 examples with service history.

concours.description: Low-mileage M3 with documented maintenance. Manual transmission and desirable colors command premium.

redFlags: N54 engine with unknown turbo or injector status
M3 without rod bearing service documentation
Check engine light with multiple codes
DCT transmission shudder or harsh engagement
Oil consumption over 1 quart per 1,000 miles
Missing maintenance records on high-mileage cars
Extensive tuning modifications without supporting upgrades
whatToLookFor: Service records showing major maintenance completed
N55 engine over N54 for improved reliability (335i)
M3 with documented rod bearing service
M Sport package for enhanced styling and suspension
Coupe (E92) body style for best looks
Lower mileage examples - these are complex cars
Colors like Le Mans Blue, Interlagos Blue, or Jerez Black M3
Working iDrive and premium sound if equipped
expertTips: The 328i with N52 engine is the most reliable option for daily driving
N54 335i is a tuner's dream but requires diligent maintenance
N55 335i (2011+) addressed many N54 reliability issues - prefer it for a driver
M3 rod bearing service is mandatory - verify completion or budget immediately
The M3's S65 V8 is one of the greatest engines BMW has ever made - worth the maintenance
Electric water pump failure can happen without warning - some owners replace preventatively
HPFP extended warranty only applies to original owner - factor this into used purchase
The 335is combines N54 power with 335i reliability updates - rare but desirable
DCT in the M3 is excellent when maintained but manual is more engaging
E90 suspension components are wear items - budget for bushings and control arms

forums.name: BimmerPost
forums.description: Comprehensive BMW forum covering all models

forums.name: BimmerBoard E90 Forum
forums.description: Technical how-to articles and expert advice

websites.name: E90Post Wiki
websites.description: E90 technical wiki and DIY guides
